description: From Middle English disdeynen, from Old French desdeignier (modern French dédaigner).

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A feeling of contempt or scorn.
examples: The cat viewed the cheap supermarket catfood with disdain and stalked away.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) That which is worthy to be disdained or regarded with contempt and aversion.
(obsolete) The state of being despised; shame.

verbs.description: disdain (third-person singular simple present disdains, present participle disdaining, simple past and past participle disdained)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To regard (someone or something) with strong contempt.
examples: When the Philistine  […]  saw David, he disdained him; for he was but a youth.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To be indignant or offended.
